content.introduction:
kubectl is the command-line tool for interacting with Kubernetes clusters. Mastering kubectl is essential for managing and troubleshooting your applications.

ðŸ“„ **Download the complete kubectl Cheat Sheet** - A comprehensive reference guide with all essential commands is available in the resources section below.

sections.title: Essential kubectl Commands
sections.content: Learn the most commonly used kubectl commands for managing resources.

codeExamples.code:
# Get resources
kubectl get pods
kubectl get deployments
kubectl get services

# Describe resources (detailed info)
kubectl describe pod my-pod

# Create resources from YAML
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

# Delete resources
kubectl delete pod my-pod
codeExamples.explanation: These commands cover the basic CRUD operations for Kubernetes resources.

sections.title: Viewing Logs and Debugging
sections.content: kubectl provides powerful commands for troubleshooting applications.

codeExamples.code:
# View Pod logs
kubectl logs my-pod

# Follow logs in real-time
kubectl logs -f my-pod

# Execute commands in a Pod
kubectl exec -it my-pod -- /bin/bash

# Port forwarding for local access
kubectl port-forward pod/my-pod 8080:80
codeExamples.explanation: These commands help you debug and interact with running Pods.

sections.title: Working with Contexts and Namespaces
sections.content: Manage multiple clusters and organize resources with contexts and namespaces.

codeExamples.code:
# View current context
kubectl config current-context

# Switch context
kubectl config use-context my-cluster

# Work with namespaces
kubectl get pods -n my-namespace
kubectl create namespace dev
codeExamples.explanation: Contexts allow you to switch between clusters, while namespaces organize resources within a cluster.

sections.title: Resource Management
sections.content: Monitor and manage resource usage in your cluster.

codeExamples.code:
# View resource usage
kubectl top nodes
kubectl top pods

# Edit resources
kubectl edit deployment my-deployment

# View events
kubectl get events --sort-by=.metadata.creationTimestamp
codeExamples.explanation: These commands help you monitor cluster health and resource consumption.

sections.title: Quick Reference - Most Used Commands
sections.content: Here's a quick reference of the commands you'll use most often. For a complete cheat sheet, see the downloadable resource below.

codeExamples.code:
# Cluster & Context
kubectl cluster-info
kubectl config current-context
kubectl config use-context <context>

# Get Resources
kubectl get pods
kubectl get pods -A                    # All namespaces
kubectl get pods -o wide               # More details

# Describe & Logs
kubectl describe pod <name>
kubectl logs <pod>
kubectl logs -f <pod>                  # Follow logs

# Create & Delete
kubectl apply -f <file.yaml>
kubectl delete pod <name>

# Execute & Debug
kubectl exec -it <pod> -- /bin/bash
kubectl port-forward <pod> 8080:80

# Scale & Update
kubectl scale deployment <name> --replicas=3
kubectl set image deployment/<name> <container>=<image>
codeExamples.explanation: These are the essential commands you'll use daily. Bookmark this section for quick reference!

sections.title: Pro Tips
sections.content: Make your kubectl experience more efficient with these tips.

codeExamples.code:
# Enable tab completion (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
source <(kubectl completion bash)      # For bash
source <(kubectl completion zsh)       # For zsh

# Useful aliases (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
alias k='kubectl'
alias kgp='kubectl get pods'
alias kgs='kubectl get services'
alias kgd='kubectl get deployments'
alias kl='kubectl logs'
alias kex='kubectl exec -it'

# Watch resources in real-time
kubectl get pods --watch

# Get help for any command
kubectl <command> --help

# Explain resource fields
kubectl explain pods
kubectl explain pods.spec.containers
codeExamples.explanation: These tips will save you time and make working with kubectl much more pleasant.

content.summary:
kubectl is your primary tool for interacting with Kubernetes. Practice these commands to become proficient in managing your cluster.
